newsitem.title: USA: NYMEX electricity ends lower in line with natgas.
newsitem.headline: NYMEX electricity ends lower in line with natgas.

text.p: NYMEX electricity futures closed mostly lower in line with weaker natural gas prices, market sources said Thursday.
"I think it (the electricity futures complex) is still a little bit fat compared with where gas is," said one trader.
But physical market prices remained strong on Wednesday amid continued above-normal temperatures in the Southwest and a rash of generating unit outages.
"Competition for that marginal megawatt is keeping daily cash prices firm," said another trader.
Still, the June Palo Verde (PV) contract closed down 23 cents at $22.73 per megawatt hour (MWh), while July lost 42 cents to settle at $25.68 and August fell 32 cents to close at $27.60.
Other PV contracts were down between 20 and 29 cents.
June California Oregon Border (COB) futures closed 13 cents lower at $16.44, while July was down 3 cents at $17.70 and August closed 5 cents down at $21.18.
Other COB contracts were down by as much as 15 cents, while far forward contracts were up as much as 30 cents.
NYMEX said that as of 1535 EDT an estimated total of 525 COB and 618 PV contracts had traded.
The NYMEX June Henry Hub natural gas contract closed down 8 cents at $2.273 per million British thermal units.

Short-term physical electricty prices rose Thursday as the market took notice of an ongoing unplanned outage at a 750 megawatt unit at the Four Corners power plant in Arizona, as well as a delay in restarting a 350 MW unit at the San Juan plant in New Mexico.
Next-day PV prices were seen as high as $34.00 a MWh, while COB was up to $18.50 and Four Corners saw $30.00.
But traders noted that forward cash prices were weaker in line with the futures market. June PV fell from over $23.00 per MWh to as low as $22.15 on Thursday, traders said.
